item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
A little application of Snell's Law (n1 sin(θ1)=n2 sin(θ2)) against a grid of materials using Cauchy refraction modeling (n(λ) = A + B/λ²)

Mapping various gradients to λ; it doesn't have to be a rainbow

#XQuery #SVG

Lightning strikes https://t.co/wA7yoz40RK

Fractures in the ice https://t.co/KjMrn3Kg6E

The arrangement of materials in the grid doesn't need to be random. Here alternation in columns can channel beams coming from certain angles.

The light trap https://t.co/onUFnRyksK

These aren't particularly realistic materials: I have the dispersion cranked to 11, as it were, and there no absorbance is modeled.

Shimmer https://t.co/pBcPFb2T7F

Sometimes the light gets trapped in a loop, so I had to add an iteration limit.

Five beams enter: four escape (you just have to trust me on that: the splitting hides the fact)

Light trying to escape from the sun https://t.co/v61HAumQbx

item.description:
Mazes

More fun with the Wave Function Collapse algorithm

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/E9UbqlWP5E

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
Fun with the Wave Function Collapse algorithm (cf https://t.co/WwfX4DRhC0)

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/Qmy6rvJC6U

This is the simple tiling variation, where you define some base tiles, their symmetries, and some L to R adjacency rules https://t.co/sSMBoK5VmM

For the gradient tiling I needed to extend the ported algorithm to introduce a couple of new symmetry types

You can get very different looks depending on whether the gradient is sequential, circular, divergent, random, or split https://t.co/hXrDV9R1KI

A random gradient https://t.co/9XGAtrUK4k
